He received his PhD degree in Computer Science from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 2003. His research focuses on product configuration, ontology based knowledge representation and object-oriented modeling.

Ming Dong is currently a Professor in Antai College of Economics & Management at Shanghai Jiao Tong University. He received his PhD in Industrial Engineering from the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in 2001. His research interests are in supply chain management, decision in product design, and production optimization.

abstract.p: Within the context of build-to-order or assembly-to-order production strategy, an end product satisfying the requirements of a customer often comprises various components or parts that may be provided by the partnering suppliers. More probably, there exist a numerous number of alternative components or parts to be chosen when an end product is configured. Meanwhile, structures and constraints within the configurable product must be observed. To represent structures of products and constraints, object-oriented modeling method is employed to enable the share and reuse of configuration knowledge. To derive optimal configuration, product configuration problem with object-oriented configuration knowledge is formalized as a mixed-integer programming problem. The algorithm for product configuration optimization is implemented using Java CPLEX. Experiments are conducted to demonstrate and compare the performance of the algorithm. The results show that the computational time is reasonable and acceptable for medium-sized configuration problems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern industry is characterized by large-scale production and highly diversified customer requirements (Huang et al., 2004; Salvador and Forza, 2004; Trentin et al., 2011). To meet the individualized customer requirements, an end product often comprises various components or parts offered by manufacturers or suppliers within the context of build-to-order (BTO) or assembly-to-order (ATO) production strategy (Gunasekarana and Ngai, 2005). For example, a Dell computer is configured by selecting components or parts from a variety of alternatives provided by its component or part manufactures. Usually, the components are designed and organized in the way of product families (Jiao et al., 1998; Tiihonen et al., 1998) with the aim of mass customization (MC) in mind. As a consequence, a numerous variants of components or alternatives are supplied by component or part manufactures. To configure an end product, the end-product manufactures should check the structural restrictions, that is, the relationships between a subcomponent and its super component, and the constraints limiting valid combination of various components and ensure that the selected components are consistent with respect to the constraints and restrictions. For instance, the CPU of AMD type is exclusive with the motherboard of Intel type. To represent the restrictions and constraints, various graphical modeling methods (such as AND–OR tree (Jiao anTseng, 1999) and information modeling approaches such as ontology (Clarizia et al., 2010) and object-oriented modeling (Ong et al., 2006) are adopted. On the other hand, the solving technologies including constraint satisfaction approach (Aldanondo and Vareilles, 2008; Fleischanderl et al., 1998; Fohn et al., 1995; Huang et al., 2008; Liu et al., 2010; Mittal and Frayman, 1989; Wang et al., 2011), case-based reasoning (Tseng et al., 2005; Xuanyuan et al., 2011), rule-based approach (Barker and O’Connor, 1989), and genetic algorithm (Hong et al., 2007; Jiang et al., 2011; Li et al., 2006; Liu and Liu, 2010; Xuanyuan et al., 2008; Yeh et al., 2007; Zhou et al., 2008) are employed to infer configuration solutions. For a long time, the two aspects of research on product configuration, namely configuration modeling and the solving technologies, are carried out independently. Recently, some researchers attempt to develop a complete configuration system that incorporates both aspects (Frutos et al., 2004; Ong et al., 2006; Yang et al., 2009). For example, Frutos et al. combine object-oriented modeling and integer programming (IP) to derive the optimal configuration (Frutos et al., 2004). Motivated by the study performed by Frutos et al. 2004, we present a hybrid approach of incorporating object-oriented modeling and mixed-integer programming (MIP) to model and solve product configuration optimization problem (COP). The focus is on developing an automatic translation from O–O models to MIP models such that optimization can be automatically derived without the necessity of mastering expertise in mathematical modeling for users, compared with the research by Frutos, which places much emphasis on framework of the configuration system. Furthermore, more complicated structural restrictions, such as OR and group composition constraints, and configuration rules, such as port-connection rules (PCRs), resource balancing rules (RBRs), and cardinality-based rules, are considered in our study, whereas configuration rules in the latter are reduced to only two kinds of rules, namely incompatible rules and compatible rules. As a consequence, we consider more complicated modeling factors in automatically translating from O–O configuration models to MIP models.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Section “Literature review” gives a review of the literature regarding product configuration problem (CP). Research methodology is addressed in section “Research methodology.” In section “Product configuration model,” object-oriented modeling, that is, Unified Modeling Language (UML), is adopted to represent structural restrictions and rules in the product configuration domain. Section “Formulating COP as a MIP” formalizes product CP as a MIP problem where structural restrictions and rules in the configuration models are expressed as constraints in the MIP. In section “Experimental results and analysis,” experiments are conducted to test and measure the performance of the optimization algorithm. Finally, section “Conclusion” summarizes the work and concludes this article.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: Concurrent engineering (CE) has been considered as one of the most effective approaches to reducing product development lead time and achieving overall cost savings through concurrently carrying out various activities in the phases of product design, manufacturing, and assembly (Prasad and Prasad, 1996; Tseng and Jiao, 1998). With the enterprises becoming more customer oriented, MC is realized in modern industry to balance the objectives for the high efficiency and low costs of mass production and the needs for meeting individualized customer requirements (Pine, 1993). MC based on CE poses new challenges in designing, manufacturing, and maintaining product families (Du et al., 2002; Huang et al., 2004; Ma et al., 2008), instead of mass production of one or several types of product in traditional CE practice. Within the context of MC for CE, products (components or parts) are designed and manufactured in the form of product family or product variants (Tseng and Jiao, 1998; Du et al., 2001). The term “configuration” or “configuration management” in current engineering means the organization and management of various materials, parts, and products among the various phases of concurrent manufacturing (Prasad and Prasad, 1996). Prasad classifies configuration in traditional CE into as-planned configuration, as-designed configuration, as-built configuration, and as-maintained configuration (Prasad and Prasad, 1996). For MC based on CE, the as-planned and as-defined configurations are concerned with capturing customer requirements and developing corresponding product families, whereas the as-built configuration concentrates on organizing the production and manufacturing of product families. After as-built configuration stage, that is, the start of the service stage, a product variant fulfilling requirements of a customer is delivered to the customer. Here, the configuration technology for product family is employed to derive a product variant to fulfill individualized customer requirements from platform-based product family architecture (PFA) (Du et al., 2002) using variety generation methods such as swapping, scaling, and attaching/removing (Du et al., 2002). Consequently, it can be seen that configuration in the context of product family, that is, product family configuration, occurs within the enterprise, namely that the modules, components, and parts involved in the configuration are manufactured by the same company.

Configuration may also occur in the enterprise that adopts BTO or ATO production strategies where parts and components are outsourced to part manufactures (Gunasekarana and Ngai, 2005). Generally, there exist a larger number of alternative components and parts supplied by partnering firms. When a customer order with individualized requirements for the end product is received, the main manufacturer is responsible for checking and selecting suitable components from suppliers to assemble them into a valid product. The technology of assembling the components into a valid product that satisfies the requirements of customers is called product configuration technology (Sabin and Weigel, 1998; Sinz et al., 2007). As a key enabling technology for MC, product configuration aims to automate the processes of configuring a valid and complete product such that customer requirements are satisfied without violating all configuration rules. Product configuration is defined to select components from the component catalog, set the properties of components and build the connections between components (Mittal and Frayman, 1989). Since successful application of the first commercially used configuration system XCON (Barker and O’Connor, 1989), configuration technology is widely employed in industries to configure a variety of products ranging from computer systems (Fohn et al., 1995) to communication device (Fleischanderl et al., 1998). Accordingly, product configuration technology has been deeply investigated by the research community. Substantial achievement has been made in solving a CP. Main technologies are constraint satisfaction approach (Aldanondo and Vareilles, 2008; Fleischanderl et al., 1998; Fohn et al., 1995; Huang et al., 2008; Liu et al., 2010; Mittal and Frayman, 1989; Wang et al., 2011), case-based reasoning (Tseng et al., 2005; Xuanyuan et al., 2011), rule-based approach (Barker and O’Connor, 1989), and genetic algorithm (Hong et al., 2007; Jiang et al., 2011; Li et al., 2006; Liu and Liu, 2010; Xuanyuan et al., 2008; Yeh et al., 2007; Zhou et al., 2008). However, the structures of products and structural restrictions among components are ignored in the aforementioned approaches (Veron and Aldanondo, 2000; Yang et al., 2009). As product configuration technology is more applied in real industrial setting where industrial products become complex in both the structures of products and components, modeling and representing product configuration models receive much attention (Felfernig et al., 2002; Frutos et al., 2004; Ong et al., 2006; Soininen et al., 1998; Yang et al., 2009; Zeng and Jin, 2007). Modeling the structures of products is of importance for putting product configuration technology into practice. The reason is that real industrial products may consist of a number of parts or components, and complicated interdependencies exist between components. An essential requirement for modeling structures of configurable products is that configuration models should be reused as much as possible, given that the parts constituting a configurable product may be upgraded or replaced due to technological advancement in the future. Object-oriented modeling (Frutos et al., 2004; Ong et al., 2006; Zeng and Jin, 2007), such as UML (Felfernig et al., 2002), and knowledge modeling, such as ontologies (Clarizia et al., 2010; Soininen et al., 1998; Yang et al., 2009), are two mainly used methods for representing product structures and constraints. As a consequence, researchers begin to combine the solving technology like constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) with configuration modeling, such as object-oriented representation, to explore CPs. For example, in Ong et al.’s (2006) study, object-oriented modeling is used to represent structures and rules of configurable bicycle and then the invasion algorithm of CSP is utilized to obtain configuration solutions. On the other hand, rule reasoning is employed as the solution technology to infer configuration results although configuration models are represented using ontology (Yang et al., 2009). However, the aforementioned approaches integrating configuration modeling and the solving technologies (such as CSP) merely focus on obtaining one or several feasible configurations. They do not handle or directly address the optimization problem, namely that of selecting optimal or near-optimal configuration from feasible configurations. Table 1 gives a comparison of the existing methods for product configuration. It can be seen that most of the existing work focus on obtaining one, multiple, or all configuration solutions, instead of the optimal solution. Optimization is only carried using the genetic algorithm, and thus, approximate optimal solution is derived. An exception is that Frutos et al. address the COP with object-oriented configuration models (Frutos et al., 2004). In their study, configuration model depicting structures and rules of products are formalized in the UML (Bruegge and Dutoit, 2007), an industrial notation for object-oriented modeling whereas IP is used to solve the optimization problem, and thus, the exact optimal configuration is derived. However, only rather simple configuration rules encompassing compatible rules and incompatible rules and structural restrictions are considered in configuration modeling and optimization. More complex structural limitations, such as OR and group composition, and configuration rules, such as cardinality-related rules, PCRs, are missing in their approaches. Motivated by the work of Frutos et al., we present a hybrid approach of integrating object-oriented modeling and MIP for solving product COPs. More complicated configuration rules, such as require rules (RRs), PCRs, and RBRs, and structural restrictions, such as OR constraints and group composition constraints, are handled in representing object-oriented configuration models and formalizing them as MIP problem. Using the hybrid approach, formulation of MIP problems is automatically generated from the object-oriented configuration models. Then Java CPLEX is used as the MIP solver for carrying out experiments to measure the performances of the presented hybrid algorithm.

sec.title: Research methodology
sec.p: Under the context of MC, an increasing number of manufacturing companies adopt BTO or ATO production strategies to provide tailored products for customers with quick responsiveness and relatively low cost. When either a customer requests quotation for a product or a sale order arrives at the sale department, the configuration system in the manufacturing firm employs product configuration technology to obtain the exact optimal configuration consisting of parts or components offered by the partnering suppliers. The structure of a configuration system that adopts a hybrid approach of solving product configuration optimization is shown in Figure 1. As shown in the figure, the product configuration model, as an input to the configuration engine, describes both structures of a product and configuration rules in the product. The configuration engine is implemented using the optimization technology. The output is the optimal configuration in the form of bill of material (BOM), which is composed of the components or parts produced by partnering suppliers. In the following sections, we address the representation of product configuration models using object-oriented modeling. Next, the focus is on formulation of such a CP with object-oriented representation as a MIP.

sec.title: Product configuration model
sec.p: Product configuration model, that is, configuration model for short, as the key of production management and organization, depicts the structures of products and configuration rules. Object-oriented modeling method provides a stable and reusable representation of structures of entities in a system. The main entities in product configuration models are components, ports, resources, and configuration rules.

list-item.p: Component is a constituent element, of which a customized product is composed, to provide some functions of a product. A component itself may be a subassembly of other component or an atomic part that cannot be further decomposed.

Port is a physical place of a component through which the component can be connected to other parts. Therefore, the port concept describes how components in a configuration are physically interconnected.

Resource represents what a component in a configuration could supply or consume. To take an example, in a personal computer configuration, hard disks supply disk capacities whereas operation systems consume disk capacities.

Attribute describes the parametric properties of a component, which can be measured using some units. For instance, an engine has the weight as its attribute. In some literatures, the attribute is also called the parameter.

sec.p: Furthermore, relationships exist between components to reflect hierarchical and structural restrictions. The inheritance relationship between components, which is categorized as XOR and OR relationship, indicates that a component (such as A) is one kind of component (such as B). XOR relationship represents that only one of the child components is selected in a product when the parent component is included. OR relationship means that one or several child components can exist in a product when the parent component is included.

Composition relationship between components represents that a component is a part of another component. Mandatory and optional are two special kinds of composition relationships. Mandatory relationship between components means that a part is required to be included in a product when the whole is selected. Optional relationship denotes that a part can be included in a product or not when the whole is selected. Moreover, group composition relationship indicates that the whole consists of several components of the same types.

More complex relationships such as has-attribute (has-port) exist to represent the own relationships between a component and its attribute (a port). Configuration rules that are specified due to economical, technical, and processing factors restrict all possible combinations of components in a valid configuration. Typical configuration rules include the RRs, the exclusion rule (ER), RBR, PCRs, and cardinality-based rules. These rules are elaborated in the following.

list-item.p: RR specifies such a relationship between two types of components, namely, one type of components that is in a configuration requires another type of components to be involved in this configuration. For instance, the existence of CPU-486 requires the existence of Intel_Motherboard in a configuration. However, the RR can be further classified into the exist-require (E-require) rule and for-each require (F-require) rule when the cardinalities of components and hierarchical structures of products are taken into account.
E-require rule. If there exists component A in a configuration, there is component B in the same configuration.
F-require rule. For each component A in a configuration, there should be a corresponding component B in the same configuration.

ER states that some types of components cannot be used together in the same final configuration, because they are incompatible. To take an example, the motherboard-AMD is incompatible with the CPU-586.

PCR stipulates which types of components should be connected through their own ports. Consequently, the port constraint depicts the connection relationships among components in a configuration. For examples, one port constraint may indicate that SCSI-Controller should be connected with motherboard-1 through their corresponding ports, that is, PCI-connector and PCI-slot.

RBR specifies that for a legal configuration, the total amount of resources consumed by components should be less than or equal to that of resources supplied by components. For instance, in a computer configuration, the total capacity of disk spaces consumed by various software installed in a computer should be less than or equal to that provided by hard disks in the computer.

sec.p: As described earlier, object-oriented modeling technique is an information modeling approach with the advantage of reusability and maintainability of models. UML, as an industrial standard for object-oriented notation, can facilitate the understanding between domain experts, modelers, and users.

To illustrate how to represent product configuration model in UML, a bus configuration case from HIGER BUS Company Limited, one of the fastest developing bus manufacturers in Suzhou, China, is used throughout this article. The HIGER BUS Company not only manufactures general buses, but also provides customized buses with specific purposes such as the buses for carrying athletes, the buses for emergency health services, and the buses to be used in the regions with extreme climates like Tibet. These customized buses need individualized configuration in the size of seats and buses, air conditioners, drinking and recreation device, etc. The product configuration model for a bus family in HIGER using UML notation is presented in Figure 2. Most of the structural relationships can be well understood by reading the model. The configuration rules, most of which are depicted in the figure, are explicated as follows:

sec.p: A valid configuration consists of a set of components that satisfy all configuration rules and structural relations specified in the product configuration model. An optimal configuration is one of the valid configurations with minimum costs according to objective function. In the following section, we show that with the objective of optimization, the COP with object-oriented product configuration representation can be formalized as a MIP problem. To read more about the use of UML for representing product models, interested readers can refer to the literature (Felfernig et al., 2002).

sec.title: Inheritance relationships
sec.p: To solve COPs, structural relationships and configuration rules in the product model need to be expressed in linear equality or inequality when mathematic programming approach is employed as the mechanism for optimization. The inheritance relationship can be categorized into XOR and OR relationships in which the former represents an exclusive choice of child components, and the latter allows selection of one or several child components simultaneously. Furthermore, a parent component with cardinality included in an inheritance relationship indicates the number of child components that are permitted to occur in a valid configuration.

sec.title: For composition relationship
sec.p: The composition relationship in a product model describes the whole-part relation or assembly relation between components. Mandatory and optional relationships are commonly used composition relationships in capturing commonality and variability of a product family. More complicated composition relationship is cardinality-based composition, which indicates the number of parts occurring in the composition or assembly relation. Constraint (7) expresses the mandatory composition relationship where existence of a part completely depends on that of the whole. The optional composition is captured by constraint (6) where the nonexistence of a part must imply that the whole is not in the configuration. Constraint (7) ensures the composition with cardinality Li..Ui, which indicates lower and upper bounds of the number of the part j, respectively.

sec.title: For the attribute relationship
sec.p: The attribute of a component may be a continuous variable (such as weight) or a discrete variable (such as color). In the case of the attribute as a continuous variable, constraints (19) and (20), in which M is the largest value that Yi can take, guarantee that the attribute should exist if and only if the corresponding component occurs in the configuration. Handling the attribute relationship when the component has a discrete variable is much tedious and very similar to that of XOR relationship. The reason is that an attribute takes only a value from a set of enumerable values. For example, the color of a car takes only a value from the set {red, green, blue} where red, green, and blue form a XOR relationship. Consequently, the representation of such attribute relationship is almost the same as the constraints (2), (3), and (4) and thus is omitted for simplicity.

sec.title: Experimental results and analysis
sec.p: Our algorithm for automatically translating object-oriented models to MIP is coded in Java and linked with ILOG CPLEX 10.1 library (ILOG, 2006) such that the optimization can be carried out. The experiment measuring the performances of the algorithm run on an Intel Core Dual T2050 computer at 1.60 GHz with 1GB of RAM, using the Window XP operating system. To generate test cases, three parameters NC, NCC, and B are employed to derive random product models that are organized in object-oriented way. NC is the total number of components, NCC is the number of configuration rules, and B is used to control the branching width of a component within a hierarchical and structured product model. Namely, B is maximum number of child components that a component can have or that of subparts that a whole part allows.

The following parameter values are used: B = 4 and NCC = 50. However, it is supposed that NC is from the set {200, 500, 1000, 2000, 4000, 5000}. The experimental results are presented in Table 3 and Figure 3. It shows that the mean total computational times increase rapidly when the number of total components increases. Although the configuration optimization is NP-hard problem, it is acceptable that solving a COP with nearly 5000 components takes only 7125 ms.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, we present a hybrid approach of integrating object-oriented modeling and MIP for solving product COPs. As a consequence, domain engineers or experts can describe the structures and rules of products in their familiar terminologies or vocabularies. The optimal configuration is then derived by automatically translating object-oriented configuration models to MIP. The advantage of the presented approach is that there is no need for the domain engineers to master complex mathematical knowledge in mathematical programming. The experimental results show that the performance of the algorithm is acceptable for medium-size product CP. Further work is to consider more constraints closely connected with BTO or ATO supply chain such as inventory limitations and delivery date restrictions in product COPs.
